5-1 Tar Heels focused on sustaining winning habits 
Posted 34 minutes ago Your friends e-mail addresses (comma separated): * Subject: * You must enter the characters with black color that stand out from the other characters More on this 
Hood: "The food tastes better, the days are sunnier." 
Williams: "Hopefully we can keep winning games, (...) getting praise" By Marilyn Payne 
Chapel Hill, N.C. — North Carolina’s 5-1 record means the Tar Heels are one win from bowl eligibility before Halloween. 
It is the first 5-1 start for the program since 2011. 
The mark is also the best start under Larry Fedora and the fourth-year UNC program leader admits it feels good. 
“It feels a whole lot better,” Fedora said. “It’s a confidence booster for a football team, it makes them feel better about everything that we’re doing – everything .” 
Everything, indeed. 
“A lot of things go a lot better whenever you start winning,” running back Elijah Hood said. “The food tastes better, the days are sunnier, everything gets a lot better for sure.” 
More important than the warm-and-fuzzies, though, is that the success continues. Following the hot start in 2011, the Tar Heels lost four of their next five games and ultimately their bowl game in finishing 7-6. 
“It’s all good when people are patting you on the back, telling you you’re doing a good job and winning games,” quarterback Marquise Williams said. “But as soon as you lose, that goes south. A lot of people are going to tell you how bad you suck and you need to do something else. It’s good when you’re winning, hopefully we can keep winning games and keep getting praise.” 
Based on the number of times it’s repeated, the 5-1, 2-0 ACC record and five-game win streak really just means the Tar Heels can’t get complacent with their success. 
“It lets you know that each game we can come out and win football games if we just execute in the game system,” Williams said. “Being 5-1, we just can’t get complacent, we’ve got to keep coming out each day in practice and executing and doing what you need to do to be 6-1, 7-1. We have to keep our foot on the gas.” 
Not that the streak or history matters to the team, but a win against Virginia (2-4, 1-1 ACC) would give the Tar Heels their longest win streak since winning eight straight in 1997. 
What does matter is that UNC wins that next game, the team insists, and there’s only one way to do it. 
“We continue to keep doing the same things. I talked about it with them the other day – don’t forget what it took to get to this point, what you’ve done, what you’ve put into it, it didn’t just happen,” Fedora said. “’You didn’t just walk out here and it happened like this.’ We want to keep doing that. 
The Carolina head coach joked that his harping on the details may go “in one ear out the other,” but he’s still doing it every day to reemphasize it. 
UNC has improved this year in the offensive line’s ability to pick up on blitzes, as recently as learning on the first two drives against Wake Forest, and in the defensive line’s ability to pass rush quarterbacks – two things coaches have harped on since training camp. 
“We’re still not as good as we want to be on it,” defensive end Dajaun Drennon said of the unit’s pass rushing. “But I’m happy to see that we are getting after it.” 
There are still three key areas where Fedora isn’t seeing what he wants from his team. The special teams unit has yet to make a game-changing play (that wasn’t waved off), the offense is inconsistent – starting slow and turning the ball over far more often than the coach and team would like – and the red zone defense is below Fedora’s desired 50 percent. 
Virginia’s record fails to reflect the quality of opponent that comes to Kenan Stadium this week, Fedora believes, leaving no room for those weaknesses to persist. 
“If you really look at Virginia, their four losses were against teams that were all ranked at one point,” he said. “They’ve played a difficult schedule. When I look at that film, I’m saying ‘That’s a good football team that’s going to come in here.’ They lost four games, but (against) UCLA, Pitt, Notre Dame, Boise State. They’re going to come into our stadium and expect to win a football game.” 
The coach gets that his impression of the foe may not be the first impression his team has of Virginia, but he’s setting his team straight. 
“I get them to the second glace real quick,” he said. 
And it seems the players understand what they’re looking at next. 
“When you play a schedule like that, it definitely toughens you up,” Hood said. “They’re used to seeing talented players, guys who can do a lot of things. So, they won’t be phased by us for sure.” Credits
